figure.title: ajf forge based on the Jboss Forge Project

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The ajf-forge is in fact a plugin for JBOSS FORGE which is a powerful project building tool. With this plugin you will be able to easily generate an empty ajf2 project, instantly deployable on a local tomcat server. It gives you the key to a "ready to use" ajf2 project.

section.title: Install forge
section.para: Installing the Jboss Forge tool will allow you to use the ajf-forge plugin.

section.title: Download forge distribution
section.para:
Download the
Jboss forge distribution.
Unzip the forge distribution in your C:/appli directory.

section.title: Set environment variables
section.para: In order for the forge to work, you have to add the JBoss Forge distribution's bin directory to the build path of your system. After right clicking on your workstation and go in properties/Environment variable section, create a variable FORGE_HOME, targeting the forge distribution directory
After that you have to add "%FORGE_HOME%/bin" to your system's path. To do so, just mofiy the "Path" environment variable :

section.title: Run JBOSS forge tool
section.para: Now you are ready to use the JBOSS Forge tool. For that, just launch a command prompt terminal and set the command :

Now you are able to use the forge tool. It works pretty much the same way as an UNIX shell. Use cd command to navigate between folders (and use almost every UNIX shell command). By tapping the TAB button of you keyboard, you'll see also all the available commands on forge

section.title: Install ajf-forge plugin
section.para: In order to generate an AJF solution you just need to install the ajf-forge plugin.
First and foremost, you have to download the AJF-FORGE-PLUGIN .
Then, unzip this Plugin folder contained in the zip file into your forge working directory. This directory is simply displayed on your terminal each time you launch the forge shell.
That's it ! Your plugin is now installed. Just quit the forge shell with the exit command, and then relaunch it.
If you now run the forge list-plugins command , you should be able to see the installed ajf-forge plugin plugin :

section.title: Use the ajf-forge Plugin
section.para: Let's now use the ajf-forge plugin to generate an ajf2 application

section.title: Attach forge's context
section.para: First and foremost, in order to run the ajf-forge plugin, you have to attach the ajf-forge-context to the shell. To do so, download the ajf-forge-context.zip file.

Unzip it in the directory that you like. (i.e : C:/myDirectory).
ajf-forge-context folder

Secondly, launch the forge Shell and navigate to this context folder (via cd command). You should see the forge prompt switch to green color written :
ajf-forge-context
attach forge shell's context

section.title: Run AJF-Forge commands
section.para: You are now ready to run the commands for AJF solution generation :
And you should now be prompted the kind of ajf project that you want to generate.

Both of the two options will work pretty much the same way. Two inputs will be prompted :
- Project name ( general name of your application, i.e: myApplication )
- Project folder : Directory where to create the application (i.e: C:/projects/myProjectFolder )
If selecting the "exploded" ajf project, several java maven projects will be generated:
In case of chosing the "compacted" project type, only the UI project will be generated.

section.title: Generate a "compacted" ajf project
section.para: On the "ajf-solution" default command prompted choice, enter "1" value in order to select choice number one corresponding to "compacted" ajf solution. Immediately, you will be prompted for the name you want to give to your application, and the folder where you want to create your project.

note.para: Entering the value 'exit' for the project name OR the project directory will allow you to escape the process !

section.title: Import you project in Eclipse
section.para: You are now ready to import your project in eclipse. For that, open your favourite IDE in an empty workspace and just hit the file submenu of Eclipse, and choose import choice menu. Then, in the "import project" window, select to import an Existing maven project.

figure.title: Import a maven project in Eclipse

section.para:
Then for the root directory, just click the browse button and navigate until selecting the parent folder of your application.
Browse parent directory of your application
After validation, you should be able to see each component of your application.

In case of a compacted project, you'll only the ui-application but in case of an exploded project, you'll have:
Components of your application

important.title: Set the JEE5_PROFILE to each project
important.para:
In order for maven to work properly, you have to set the maven JEE5_PROFILE to
EACH
of your project in Eclipse. For that, right click on the project and select the Properties option. Then find the maven label on the left panel, and set the JEE5_PROFILE to your project.

figure.title: Set maven JEE5_PROFILE to your project

important.para: In case of using a compacted ajf-project, you'll have to do it to your only myApplication-ui project. But in case of using an exploded ajf-solution, you'll have to do this operation on every single project of the solution

section.title: Deploy ui application on embedded tomcat
section.para:
As seen in the previous chapter , you are easily able to deploy your web UI application via the embedded maven tomcat7 applications server plugin that is already set on your AJF2 solution. To do so you just have to launch the maven command, which can be set directly in eclipse. For that, just head to the run configuration menu of eclipse via :
"run configuration" menu of Eclipse

Then, double-click on the left panel the Maven build option. And then, on the right panel, set as follow :
Use the Browse Workspace... button to select Base Directory of your UI application
Set the maven command to deploy on tomcat
After that, you'll be able to run it via the run button. And you should see in the Eclipse's console the maven logs.
At the end of the process, you can check the welcome page of your application via going to localhost:8080/ myApplication -ui

important.title: Particularity for exploded projects
important.para:
In the case of an exploded project (i.e named myApplication ), the web user interface project myApplication-ui project has internal dependencies to the myApplication-core and myApplication-config projects. If you launch directly the deployment on tomcat via the maven plugin, you may encounter the following error :
[]INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] BUILD FAILURE [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] Total time: 4.296s [INFO] Finished at: Fri Mar 23 14:52:14 CET 2012 [INFO] Final Memory: 5M/15M [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project myApplication-ui: Could not resolve dependencies for project am.projects.myApplication:myApplication-ui:war:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT: The following artifacts could not be resolved: am.projects.myApplication:myApplication-config:jar:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT, am.projects.myApplication:myApplication-core:jar:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT: Could not find artifact am.projects.myApplication:myApplication-config:jar:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT in nexus (http://web-maven-repo.appli armony.net/nexus/content/groups/public) -> [Help 1] [ERROR] [ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e swit ch. [ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging. [ERROR] [ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please rea d the following articles: [ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/DependencyReso lutionException
This is because maven is trying to resolve those dependencies... But in fact, as you just generated your exploded solution, those dependencies do not exist on your local maven repository.
To fix this, you have to :

callout.para: Run a maven clean install on the LIB project : myApplication-lib
Run a maven clean install on the PARENT project : myApplication-parent

important.para:
To do so, you can either do it directly via the windows command prompt terminal by running the following command:
C:/(...)/myApplication-lib>mvn clean install -P JEE5_PROFILE C:/(...)/myApplication-parent>mvn clean install -P JEE5_PROFILE

Or you can do it directly in Eclipse, by right clicking on the project and doing Run as / Maven Install
Maven install of a project in eclipse

blockquote.para: You must have the m2eclipse plugin to do this. If you don't have it, just catch it here.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: Here is a short List of errors that could occured when using the forge. You may found a few solutions to your problem here

section.title: AJF Project generation Error
section.para: You may encouter this error when launching the forge and trying to use directly the forge plugin.
section.screen: START generating ajf project compacted Error occured during ajf web project generation : org.jboss.forge.project.ProjectModelException: Could not create Maven project building request ***ERROR*** AJF project generation process has thrown an Exception : java.lang.N ullPointerException
section.para: This Error is due to the fact that the forge tool has never had it's context attached.
If you encounter this error:

listitem.para: Firstly, exit the forge tool and then relaunch it.
Secondly, try to attach your forge's context before launching the AJF plugin again.
